intro: Asclepias jorgeana, commonly known as the Mexican milkweed, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the milkweed family (Asclepiadaceae) and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces distinctive seed pods that split open to release silky-haired seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy species suitable for xeriscaping. Asclepias jorgeana is also an important host plant for monarch butterflies, supporting their life cycle.
